revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-06 15:14:22.000000000', 'message': "Do not run tempest.scenario.test_network* tests in nova-next

The test_network* scenario tests in tempest take a really long
time. For example, the tempest.scenario.test_network_v6.TestGettingAddress
tests in one job (that timed out) took ~35 minutes.

We already run test network scenario tests in the tempest-slow job
so let's just let that job handle these and exclude them from
nova-next.

Change-Id: I9c7fc0f0b0937f04c5b3ab9c5e8fff21c4232b86
"}]
commit_message:
Do not run tempest.scenario.test_network* tests in nova-next

The test_network* scenario tests in tempest take a really long
time. For example, the tempest.scenario.test_network_v6.TestGettingAddress
tests in one job (that timed out) took ~35 minutes.

We already run test network scenario tests in the tempest-slow job
so let's just let that job handle these and exclude them from
nova-next.

Change-Id: I9c7fc0f0b0937f04c5b3ab9c5e8fff21c4232b86

commit_message:
Add a more robust method to check OVSDB values in BaseOVSTestCase

Sometimes, when the OVSDB is too loaded (that could happen during the
functional tests), there is a delay between the OVSDB post transaction
end and when the register (new or updated) can be read. Although this is
something that should not happen (considering the OVSDB is transactional),
tests should deal with this inconvenience and provide a robust method to
retrieve a value and at the same time check the value. This new method
should provide a retrieving mechanism to read again the value in case of
discordance.

In order to solve the gate problem ASAP, another bug is fixed in this
patch: to skip the QoS removal when OVS agent is initialized during
funtional tests

When executing functional tests, several OVS QoS policies specific for
minimum bandwidth rules [1]. Because during the functional tests
execution several threads can create more than one minimum bandwidth
QoS policy (something in a production environment cannot happen), the
OVS QoS driver must skip the execution of [2] to avoid removing other
QoS created in parellel in other tests.

This patch is marking as unstable "test_min_bw_qos_policy_rule_lifecycle"
and "test_bw_limit_qos_port_removed". Those tests will be investigated
once the CI gates are stable.

[1] Those QoS policies are created only to hold minimum bandwidth rules.
    Those policies are marked with:
       external_ids: {'_type'='minimum_bandwidth'}
[2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/d6fba30781c5f4e63beeda04d065226660fc92b6/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/agent/extension_drivers/qos_driver.py#L43

Closes-Bug: #1818613
Closes-Bug: #1818859
Related-Bug: #1819125

Change-Id: Ia725cc1b36bc3630d2891f86f76b13c16f6cc37c

Questions that need to be answered from today's nova meeting:

(9:28:08 AM) dansmith: just curious, but EC implies some amount of overhead for the parity data.. does ceph hide that in what it tells us is free space if enabled?
(9:28:44 AM) melwitt: from what I understand about what jmlowe said, ceph will not hide that in what it tells for usage
(9:28:55 AM) dansmith: usage or free space?
(9:29:27 AM) dansmith: if usage then our allocations don't really line up with the inventory and we need to have some reserved amount to cover the overhead I guess?
(9:30:11 AM) melwitt: oh, yeah that's a good point to bring up
(9:30:30 AM) melwitt: he had said usage but I don't know if that applies to free space too
(9:30:57 AM) dansmith: melwitt: those kind of questions are what I'd ask in a spec, FWIW"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-07-12 14:38:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Erasure coded pools for rbd have been supported since the ceph

commit_message:
Option needed for ceph rbd erasure coding support

Erasure coded pools for rbd have been supported since the ceph
luminous release. To use this feature the erasure coded pool where
the data will be held needs to be specified during rbd device creation.
The images_rbd_pool option still needs to point to a replicated pool where
a small amount of metadata will be stored in OMAP. Currently the
driver implicitly uses the default value of None. In the case where
the clone goes back into the image pool the data pool is inherited from the
parent.

Change-Id: I4ef8c1afd08f29627718e008c9b1fdbba121d1df
Implements: blueprint rbd-erasure-coding

commit_message:
Virt driver: Build guest xml

This patch is responsible for:
1. Populating the InstanceNUMATopology object with requested
   numa topology for guest.
2. Provides the new InstanceNUMATopology object to NUMATopology
   filter and for claiming the resources to compute.
2. Building guest xml at driver side with the help of new
   InstanceNUMATopology object.

Partially Implements: blueprint cpu-resources
Change-Id: Ib78522ecaf3e95177775642786d199c5142a7025

commit_message:
Report PCPU to placement

This patch is responsible to do following things:
* Add below conf option under 'compute' section:
    [compute]
    cpu_dedicated_set

* Parse new config option CONF.compute.cpu_dedicated_set
  at libvirt driver side
* Populate the 'pcpuset' field of NUMACell object
* Report PCPU inventory to placement

Partially Implements: blueprint cpu-resources
Change-Id: I5750ef27ea6adef46895c982657b22f0c7fb0402

[{'created': '2018-09-17 11:31:42.000000000', 'message': 'Deprecate ComputeCapabilitiesFilter

Help accelerate the transition from capabilities to traits by
deprecating the ComputeCapabilitiesFilter.

This includes deprecating the logic to push capabilities from ironic
into Nova, traits should also be used there instead.
While Ironic flavors still are allowed to request capabilities and push
them down into Ironic nodes, because they have not yet all been moved to
traits.

It is expected that capabilities checks can be converted to a trait,
such as a check for more than two GPUs could be converted to a Custom
trait that is used to report any host that has more than two GPUs. This
can then be used via Placement.

Change-Id: Ifa43bca0f84382fb2ffc154e7128eb9d7ad3f905
'}]
commit_message:
Deprecate ComputeCapabilitiesFilter

Help accelerate the transition from capabilities to traits by
deprecating the ComputeCapabilitiesFilter.

This includes deprecating the logic to push capabilities from ironic
into Nova, traits should also be used there instead.
While Ironic flavors still are allowed to request capabilities and push
them down into Ironic nodes, because they have not yet all been moved to
traits.

It is expected that capabilities checks can be converted to a trait,
such as a check for more than two GPUs could be converted to a Custom
trait that is used to report any host that has more than two GPUs. This
can then be used via Placement.

Change-Id: Ifa43bca0f84382fb2ffc154e7128eb9d7ad3f905

commit_message:
docs: mark rbd driver support for extending an in-use volume

As of nova change I5698e451861828a8b1240d046d1610d8d37ca5a2
in Stein users are able to extend the size of in-use rbd volumes
with the libvirt compute driver.

This is tested in the ceph CI job with change
I6b2575b12fdb9636f106b3ca28681e29ad3eb8ac.

Related to nova blueprint extend-in-use-rbd-volumes

Change-Id: Iad35fa2d1b18a9becb2ef052d9a04af7259dded8

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 26476, 'date': '2017-07-24 21:05:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 20040, 'date': '2017-07-24 22:30:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-07-24 21:04:31.000000000', 'message': "Closes-Bug: 1702475

Minor code changes to include any IPv6 address assigned to a VM as part of the EC2 metadata service info
This adds 'local-ipv6' similar to 'local-ipv4'

It would also be useful to have the IPv6 prefix length - but that requires more extensive changes

Change-Id: I5e74046cce9ba7dbd28aef294ec82a16636dfa7d
Signed-off-by: Jeroen van Bemmel <jeroen.van_bemmel@nokia.com>
"}, {'created': '2017-07-24 21:05:21.000000000', 'message': "Closes-Bug: 1702475

Minor code changes to include any IPv6 address assigned to a VM as part of the
EC2 metadata service info. This adds 'local-ipv6' similar to 'local-ipv4'

It would also be useful to have the IPv6 prefix length - but that requires
more extensive changes

Change-Id: I5e74046cce9ba7dbd28aef294ec82a16636dfa7d
Signed-off-by: Jeroen van Bemmel <jeroen.van_bemmel@nokia.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Closes-Bug: 1702475

Minor code changes to include any IPv6 address assigned to a VM as part of the
EC2 metadata service info. This adds 'local-ipv6' similar to 'local-ipv4'

It would also be useful to have the IPv6 prefix length - but that requires
more extensive changes

Change-Id: I5e74046cce9ba7dbd28aef294ec82a16636dfa7d
Signed-off-by: Jeroen van Bemmel <jeroen.van_bemmel@nokia.com>

recheck'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-01-07 21:44:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-01-08 15:06:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-01-09 20:14:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-01-10 17:50:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-01-18 21:10:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Wanted to provide an update.  The tempest tests are passing now when I run them on a random xenial VM, but consistently failing when run by zuul.  I am looking into whether changes to the manila-tempest-plugin may resolve this issue.  Any additional information around how to troubleshoot failed zuul gates would be appreciated.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2019-01-19 13:27:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Michael,

/etc/manila/manila.conf is setting manila up to run with two back ends, one lvm and one "generic".  Running tempest with heterogenous back ends would be pretty complicated (we don't do it in manila CI).  I recommend running with lvm only to start.  So in manila.conf, s/enabled_share_backends=generic,nfs-share1/enabled_share_backends=nfs-share1/

The set of tempest tests to run and the contents of [share] section in tempest.conf depend on the configured back end.

In CI our lvm back end job runs with this command [1] and the [share] section is like this [2].  That job runs with two lvm back ends.  You probably just want to start with one and don't run ipv6 tests.

[1]  http://logs.openstack.org/76/619576/3/check/manila-tempest-minimal-dsvm-lvm/41dd811/job-output.txt.gz#_2019-01-09_19_19_58_346841

[2] http://logs.openstack.org/76/619576/3/check/manila-tempest-minimal-dsvm-lvm/41dd811/logs/tempest_conf.txt.gz'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-01-21 13:32:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-01-24 14:01:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-01-25 01:42:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2019-01-25 02:42:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2019-01-31 21:24:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15: Patch Set 14 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2019-01-31 23:14:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-02-04 20:17:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2019-02-04 20:50:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-02-05 13:22:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

Status update:  The issue with the source gate has been resolved.  The flavor size was too large and nova was running out of disk capacity.  Reducing the flavor size has resolved that issue.

The distro_install gate is running out of memory.  It passes consistently on a 15G instance, but fails every time when running on an 8G RAM instance.  The distro gate uses approx 2G more memory than the source gate.  I have been looking for ways to reduce the amount of memory consumed by the distro_install gate, but so far none of the changes have freed up enough memory to keep the OOM killer from failing the tempest tests.

Any thoughts on why the distro gate is using more memory than the source gate and how I can reduce the memory usage so the gate will pass?  Are there other examples of distro install gates that deploy keystone, nova, cinder and glance that are running at 8G of memory that I could look at to compare configuration?'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-02-05 15:31:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

Michael

Could you toss my keys in a 16G instance and I can dig into it?

https://github.com/mnaser.keys'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-02-06 13:51:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

Ok.  I got the distro_install gate to pass with the addition of the 3 changes listed below.  The current state of distro install will install all packages on all hosts/containers even if those packages are not used.  And apt is automatically starting all of the services leaving the unmanaged services running.  These extra unused services consumed enough memory to cause the gate to fail.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/633277/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/633276/

[{'created': '2018-10-19 18:11:16.000000000', 'message': 'Converting os_cinder role to os_manila role

Starting this new role by copying the os_cinder role due to the
similarities between the two openstack project.  I wanted to carry
forward existing OSA practices and not reinvent a perfectly good wheel.
The role has been modified to deploy manila on ubuntu and hopefully all
references to cinder or cinder specific configuration has been removed.

Change-Id: Ibda073e5aaa6df3b254961d4aed3a8d5961f3432

commit_message:
Basic working os_manila role

Starting this new role as a copy of the os_cinder role due to the
similarities between the two openstack projects.  This role will
deploy manila api, scheduler and share services on ubuntu with the
default local LVM backed NFS scenario.

Change-Id: Ibda073e5aaa6df3b254961d4aed3a8d5961f3432

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-01 14:35:17.000000000', 'message': "Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I24d730a1e0c46cc292923aceb8bae8d0856b6798
"}]
commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I24d730a1e0c46cc292923aceb8bae8d0856b6798

commit_message:
Get rid of setUpClass and block it for forever

setUpClass is evil. It lures you in to a sense of complacency thinking
that reality exists and makes sense. But it's all just a cruel joke
designed to increase your personal karmic debt.

In order that we might collectively one day reach nirvana, remove all
senseless and misleading instances of setUpClass. Then add local hacking
checks to prevent the introduction of such scourge ever again.

Change-Id: Ifd43958bf47981aedad639bef61769ddb37618d3

commit_message:
update gate test for removal of force evacuate

micro-version 2.68 removed force evacuation, this chage
updates gate/test_evacuate.sh to use micro-version 2.67

Closes-Bug: #1819166

commit_message:
Remove umount from volume.filters

Use umount to umount volumes via oslo.privsep.

Change-Id: I83972fbfaf0842800c65ed8c391e2089de9807fe
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chucks@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Configure taskflow connection

In patch [1], a new config option `connection` is introduced
in a new section `taskflow`  to save the recovery workflow
details of the notification.

This patch configures this new config option during creation
of config files in devstack setup.

[1] : https://review.openstack.org/#/c/640798/

Change-Id: I2383aaefaeb522e1783e2769e78438410b8033f3

commit_message:
Fix updates to the provider driver guide.

Recent patches have missed some updates to the provider driver guide.
This patch corrects those oversights.

commit_message:
Functional tests for notification APIs

This patch adds functional tests to check the behaviour
of notification APIs for notification types:-

a) Process
b) VM

Change-Id: I06b17e388773db5fb9ade31d70ee4b2ad8aefabf

commit_message:
Add implementation of VIP Port Creation in OVN

Currently OVN Octavia provider driver doesnt create the VIP port.
It was earlier created by Octavia, but recently the Provider Driver
implementation has changed and now the port needs to be created by
Driver. This patch resolves the same.

It also bumps octavia-lib version missed in Change-Id
I9542669c1f7f16c6ce8a7a10afcbf7f563f35919.

Closes-Bug:#1818026
Change-Id: I454522f9dcc7c2f5d71cb762c6bac775abd9d6f3

(1 comment)

OK, so the issue here is that a user will see many more "row archived" messages than were specified in --max-rows because of the archive==deletion of API records. Seems reasonable to treat this as a documentation issue rather than letting --max-rows encompass extra related API records that the user probably doesn't have a concept about. Another thing that comes to mind is, could we just not output "row archived" messages or numbers for related API records? Is that information helpful to a user at all?'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-10-03 19:50:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> (1 comment)
 >

 > a documentation issue rather than letting --max-rows encompass
 > extra related API records that the user probably doesn't have a
 > concept about. Another thing that comes to mind is, could we just
 > not output "row archived" messages or numbers for related API
 > records? Is that information helpful to a user at all?

I just had a look at the nova-manage code for archive_deleted_rows and we're intentionally showing instance_mappings, request_specs, and instance_group_member numbers. So indeed it seems like being more clear in the documentation is the right way to go.'}, {'account_id': 26936, 'date': '2018-10-04 08:05:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Update --max-rows parameter description for archive_deleted_rows

Since API tables do not have the concept of soft-delete, we purge
the instance_mappings, request_specs and instance_group_member records
of deleted instances while they are archived. The ``nova-manage db
archive_deleted_rows`` offers a ``max-rows`` parameter which actually
means the batch size of the iteration for moving the soft-deleted
records from table to their shadow-tables. So this patch clarifies
that the batch size does not include the API table records that are
purged so that the users are not confused by the ``--verbose`` output
of the command giving more rows than specified.

Change-Id: I652854c7192b996a33ed343a51a0fd8c7620e876
Closes-Bug: #1794994

commit_message:
Support server create with ports having resource request

A new API microversion, 2.72, is added that enables support for Neutron
ports having resource request during server create.

Note that server delete and port detach operations already handle such
ports and will clean up the allocation properly.

Change-Id: I7555914473e16782d8ba4513a09ce45679962c14
blueprint: bandwidth-resource-provider

commit_message:
Report data to conductor

Cyborg agent calls acc_driver to collect infomation of current
node. Then it should report the data object to conductor to do
the diff and store in db.

Change-Id: Ic187993019b74e70397aab50c21988c2172a5e86

commit_message:
Update minimal acceptable glanceclient

Increase the minimum version for python-glanceclient so that
Cinder can take advantage of secure hash download verification.

Change-Id: I2c3ccce45f67c6d2dc185475c478360982a98012
Closes-bug: #1818684

[{'created': '2019-03-01 18:28:35.000000000', 'message': "Parse <emulator> elements from virConnectGetCapabilities()

Ongoing / future work such as SEV[0] and the move of the default machine
type to q35[1] will need to invoke virConnectGetDomainCapabilities()
in order to check whether SEV or q35 respectively are supported.
However this API requires 5 parameters[2]:

   1) the path to the emulator binary (e.g. qemu-system-x86_64)
   2) the domain architecture
   3) the machine type
   4) the virtualization type
   5) flags (not used yet)

4) is determined by CONF.libvirt.virt_type.  The caller of
virConnectGetDomainCapabilities() can decide which combinations of 2)
and 3) type to pass[3], but still needs to know 1).  Once 2) and 3)
are known, this can be determined from the <emulator> elements
returned by libvirt's virConnectGetCapabilities() API[4].  nova
already calls this and parses the response into a LibvirtConfigCaps
object.  However currently the parser ignores the <emulator> elements.

So extend the associated LibvirtConfigCapsGuest class so that it can
parse and store <emulator> elements in a way which can be reused in
subsequent commits by callers of virConnectGetDomainCapabilities().

    most likely overkill:
    https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1683471#c7
[4] https://libvirt.org/formatcaps.html#elementGuest

commit_message:
Parse <emulator> elements from virConnectGetCapabilities()

Extend the associated LibvirtConfigCapsGuest class so that it can
parse and store <emulator> elements in a way which can be reused in
subsequent commits by callers of virConnectGetDomainCapabilities().

Ongoing / future work such as SEV[0] and the move of the default machine
type to q35[1] will need to invoke virConnectGetDomainCapabilities()
in order to check whether SEV or q35 respectively are supported.
However this API requires 5 parameters[2]:

   1) the path to the emulator binary (e.g. qemu-system-x86_64)
   2) the domain architecture
   3) the machine type
   4) the virtualization type
   5) flags (not used yet)

4) is determined by CONF.libvirt.virt_type.  The caller of
virConnectGetDomainCapabilities() can decide which combinations of 2)
and 3) type to pass[3], but still needs to know 1).  Once 2) and 3)
are known, this can be determined from the <emulator> elements
returned by libvirt's virConnectGetCapabilities() API[4].  nova
already calls this and parses the response into a LibvirtConfigCaps
object.  However currently the parser ignores the <emulator> elements.
This patch fixes that.

[0] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/stein/approved/amd-sev-libvirt-support.html
[1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/handle-default-machine-type-as-q35
[2] https://libvirt.org/html/libvirt-libvirt-domain.html#virConnectGetDomainCapabilities
[3] Calling virConnectGetDomainCapabilities for every machine type is
    most likely overkill:
    https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1683471#c7
[4] https://libvirt.org/formatcaps.html#elementGuest

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
blueprint: handle-default-machine-type-as-q35
Change-Id: Ibdc88bc5e0a214bff36a8351a1b76980f7015d16

commit_message:
Stub out port binding create/delete in NeutronFixture

This is needed for functional tests that are going to
use the NeutronFixture for operations that require
dealing with port bindings.

The NeutronFixture.list_extensions stub is also fleshed
out to include a response with the binding-extended
extension which is what's used from the neutron.api.API
supports_port_binding_extension method and without that
we don't create/delete port bindings via that API anyway.

Change-Id: Ie3c19e524679cd8bb2314aeadfad9623d1fefc8e

The ml2_conf.ini:
[ml2_type_vlan]
network_vlan_ranges = vlan:1000:2000

The current design considers network segment range as a purely logic resource, see [1] for further details. Thus, it does not exactly "care" whether a race condition happens

 > (2 comments)
 > 
 > How does this implementation prevent the race condition between
 > directly create network with specific vlan id and add new vlan
 > range? neutron now supports create network with a segment id that
 > does not set in the ml2 config file, for instance:
 > 
 > The ml2_conf.ini:
 > [ml2_type_vlan]
 > network_vlan_ranges = vlan:1000:2000
 > 
 > The network create command:
 > $ neutron net-create --provider:network_type vlan --provider:physical_network
 > vlan --provider:segmentation_id 100 test_vlan_100

The current design considers network segment range as a purely logic resource, see [1] for further details. Thus, it does not exactly "care" whether a race condition happens between directly creating a network with specific vlan id and adding a new vlan range. We'll allow that creation of new vlan range, but always rely on the underlying ML2 segment allocation DB tables/type drivers to handle the race when doing an actual segment allocation by a tenant.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/599980/'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2018-12-14 02:42:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks for the update Kailun.  
Please note the following:
1. Network segment range create needs to prevent overlapping network segment ranges.   Tenant networks must not be allowed to share the same segment ID.  This needs to prevent overlap per-physical network.  We want to support overlap across different physical networks.

2. The user interface currently requires that either --private or --shared must be specified.  The project attribute is mandatory if --shared is not specified since it doesn’t make sense to have a segment range that is not scoped to tenant if it is not shared.  This can be defaulted to the current project if not specified and shared is not specified.'}, {'account_id': 28373, 'date': '2019-02-14 05:50:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 20.'}, {'account_id': 28373, 'date': '2019-02-14 05:55:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 20:

> Thanks for the update Kailun.
 > Please note the following:
 > 1. Network segment range create needs to prevent overlapping
 > network segment ranges.   Tenant networks must not be allowed to
 > share the same segment ID.  This needs to prevent overlap
 > per-physical network.  We want to support overlap across different
 > physical networks.
 > 
 > 2. The user interface currently requires that either --private or
 > --shared must be specified.  The project attribute is mandatory if
 > --shared is not specified since it doesn’t make sense to have a
 > segment range that is not scoped to tenant if it is not shared. 
 > This can be defaulted to the current project if not specified and
 > shared is not specified.

John, thanks for the comments.
For 1), we may support overlapping prevention in a follow-up separate patch if needed.
For 2), please kindly check https://review.openstack.org/#/c/625544/ later. I'll make an update there."}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-02-14 07:26:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

(3 comments)

Besides the 'network-segment-range' itself CURD test cases, where I can see some cases like this in neutron:
(1) create network-segment-ranges, and then create a network using one segment id of it
(seems already have in neutron-tempest-plugin)
(2) create network-segment-ranges and create a network with segment_id not belong to any range.
(3) after (1), try to remove segment range which is still in-use.
(also it is in neutron-tempest-plugin patch)
(4) create a range has only one available segment_id, and parallelly 2 or more create networks try to get a segment.
something more like the functional test case from neutron itself.
IMO, you can find more reasonable scenarios for testing."}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-02-25 12:47:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25:

Based on the discussions during the team meeting on 3/4: http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/networking/2019/networking.2019-03-04-21.01.log.txt, team decides not to plan for a lib re-release and we should not be landing any PY code in lib until we solidify neutron for stein except for the API ref: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/640633/.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-12 14:32:57.000000000', 'message': 'Support Network Segment Range CRUD as extensions

This patch adds the support for network segment range CRUD. Subsequent
patches will be added to use this network segment range on segment
allocation if this extension is loaded.

Changes include:
- an API extension which exposes the segment range to be administered;
- a new network segment range DB table, model along with operation
  logic;
- Oslo Versioned Objects for network segment range data model;
- necessary changes to ML2 plugin and plugin manager to support the
  basic functions;
- a new config option in [1]_ for the feature enabling/disabling.

[1] /etc/neutron/neutron.conf

Co-authored-by: Allain Legacy <Allain.legacy@windriver.com>

Partially-implements: blueprint network-segment-range-management
Change-Id: I75814e50b2c9402fe6776229d469745d7a72290b

- a new network segment range DB table, model along with operation
  logic;
- Oslo Versioned Objects for network segment range data model;
- necessary changes to ML2 plugin and plugin manager to support the
  basic functions;
- a new config option in [1]_ for the feature enabling/disabling;
- policy-in-code support for network segment range.

[1] /etc/neutron/neutron.conf

Co-authored-by: Allain Legacy <Allain.legacy@windriver.com>

Depends-on: https://review.openstack.org/626500
Depends-on: https://review.openstack.org/626866

Partially-implements: blueprint network-segment-range-management
Change-Id: I75814e50b2c9402fe6776229d469745d7a72290b

commit_message:
Replace ostestr with stestr in testing framework.

A system upgrade broke ostestr. We can fix it by just calling stestr
directly.

Change-Id: Ic14787c7fa9ee4936cc8e098511b87a53b93c731

Replace ostestr with stestr in testing framework.

A system upgrade broke ostestr. We can fix it by just calling stestr
directly.

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-04 10:08:44.000000000', 'message': "Delay check CI jobs until the pep8/unit passes..

..for Greater Good.
Save CI resources and shorten wait-in-zuul-queue times
for other patches, when tox/pep8 checks failed.

For core openstack python projects it might make sense to
not split them apart and run them all together. For things like
TripleO/Kolla/Puppet/etc where we have layers of interactions that can
be affected by the results from the linters/unit jobs it makes
sense to split them out.

For example, in tripleo since we use packages, if the unit test fails
the integration test may fail because when we go to built the package
with the new source, the unit test int he package build fails.  Thus
we know that'll be a wasted execution and you won't actually get any
results.

An alternative Today:
  patchset one:
    pep8 SUCCESS
    unittest FAILURE
    integration FAILURE
  patchset two:
    pep8 SUCCESS
    unittest SUCCESS
    integration FAILURE
  patchset three:
    pep8 SUCCESS
    unittest SUCCESS
    integration SUCCESS

Future:
  patchset one:
    pep8 SUCCESS
    unittest FAILURE
    integration SKIPPED
  patchset two:
    pep8 SUCCESS
    unittest SUCCESS
    integration FAILURE
  patchset three:
    pep8 SUCCESS
    unittest SUCCESS
    integration SUCCESS

This may not be true for devstack but if the unit
tests are failing, then the code is likely bad (backwards
compatibility/wrong assumptions about change/etc) and we shouldn't be
running an actual deployment.

Related upstream ML threads:
* http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/
127869.html
* http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/
2019-February/003142.html

Change-Id: I60dfb82cf4020fa64ed6952f7f0fb9f49899d91f
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Delay check CI jobs until the pep8/unit passes..

..for Greater Good.
Save CI resources and shorten wait-in-zuul-queue times
for other patches, when tox/pep8 checks failed.

NOTE: for example, standalone jobs are defined as a template in
tripleo-ci, and here we are adding and override the listed jobs for the
dependencies/files options. If a job is added to the standlone template
in tripleo-ci, we need to add the job and dependency here manually.
If we won't, that job will be consumed as is and run w/o dependencies.
That is the price to pay for not having overrides managed centrally in
tripleo-ci. The latter wouldn't work neither as a single template
cannot fit all the specific needs of numerous tripleo repos. So the
final call was made to manage overrides via local overrides for tripleo
repos.

For core openstack python projects it might make sense to
not split them apart and run them all together. For things like
TripleO/Kolla/Puppet/etc where we have layers of interactions that can
be affected by the results from the linters/unit jobs it makes
sense to split them out.

For example, in tripleo since we use packages, if the unit test fails
the integration test may fail because when we go to built the package
with the new source, the unit test int he package build fails.  Thus
we know that'll be a wasted execution and you won't actually get any
results.

An alternative Today:
  patchset one:
    pep8 SUCCESS
    unittest FAILURE
    integration FAILURE
  patchset two:
    pep8 SUCCESS
    unittest SUCCESS
    integration FAILURE
  patchset three:
    pep8 SUCCESS
    unittest SUCCESS
    integration SUCCESS

Future:
  patchset one:
    pep8 SUCCESS
    unittest FAILURE
    integration SKIPPED
  patchset two:
    pep8 SUCCESS
    unittest SUCCESS
    integration FAILURE
  patchset three:
    pep8 SUCCESS
    unittest SUCCESS
    integration SUCCESS

This may not be true for devstack but if the unit
tests are failing, then the code is likely bad (backwards
compatibility/wrong assumptions about change/etc) and we shouldn't be
running an actual deployment.

Related upstream ML threads:
* http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/
127869.html
* http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/
2019-February/003142.html

Change-Id: I60dfb82cf4020fa64ed6952f7f0fb9f49899d91f
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Mock router info functions for a functional case

In functional test environment, seems L3 agent can not handle
such 30+ routers in the test test_router_processing_pool_size.
It still meets timeout for some processing procedure.
For now, router initialize/process/delete is not our test purpose
for this case, so we just mock them.

Closes-Bug: #1816239
Change-Id: I85dc6fd9d98a6a13bbf35ee2e67ce6f69be48dde

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-06 13:14:20.000000000', 'message': "Set concurrency default value

This commit sets the default value 0 for tempest run command.
Because stestr's run_command() requires an int value for that, but we
passes `None` if users don't specify a concurrency value. We found that
behavior with recent stestr change[0]. But we also have the bug in
tempest side.

[0] https://github.com/mtreinish/stestr/issues/231

Change-Id: I83f76acb6a106f7401904a910a5dced47c2db839
"}]
commit_message:
Set concurrency default value

This commit sets the default value 0 for tempest run command.
Because stestr's run_command() requires an int value for that, but we
passes `None` if users don't specify a concurrency value. We found that
behavior with recent stestr change[0]. But we also have the bug in
tempest side.

[0] https://github.com/mtreinish/stestr/issues/231

Change-Id: I83f76acb6a106f7401904a910a5dced47c2db839

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-07 20:49:56.000000000', 'message': ' _get_system_uuid function in the os_brick/initiator/connectors/nvme.py line#64 is returning uuid with trailing newline character. removed new line before function return.

Change-Id: Ibe37a14f67ce7452f088d7913a76c6233202ccea
Closes-Bug: #1819062
'}, {'created': '2019-03-08 08:35:28.000000000', 'message': 'Remove trailing newline character in UUID

Trailing newline character is present in UUID returned by
_get_system_uuid method. This causes problems when the returned UUID
is not checked for newline. Remove trailing newline before returning
UUID.

Change-Id: Ibe37a14f67ce7452f088d7913a76c6233202ccea
Closes-Bug: #1819062
'}]
commit_message:
Remove trailing newline character in UUID

Trailing newline character is present in UUID returned by
_get_system_uuid method. This causes problems when the returned UUID
is not checked for newline. Remove trailing newline before returning
UUID.

Change-Id: Ibe37a14f67ce7452f088d7913a76c6233202ccea
Closes-Bug: #1819062

commit_message:
Update json module to jsonutils

oslo project provide jsonutils, and fuelclient it
in many place[1], this PS to update the remained json module to
oslo jsonutils for consistency.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/python-fuelclient/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=jsonutils&type=

Change-Id: Idbe803a543cd8180a2d8d1ec1f15904d938da387

commit_message:
Add mistral_role_project_group

We need this var to determine which host group
to check for members of before building the
pip packages required by this role.

Change-Id: I46b9836b2c97db2306060e0e7b665c9564907633

subject: Reorder objects.resource_provider
messages:
[{'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-03-08 20:11:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-03-08 20:15:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I almost didn't do this one. It was so much change.

But I think it helps to make it even more obvious than it already was that there is a lot of chaos in the resource provider handling and rather than masking that I think we want to surface it so it is visible and doesn't surprise us, but also because it might make us more inclined to do further tidies.

/me is being an idealist again"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-03-08 21:47:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Phew.

Pulled this down and reshuffled until no diff. I can once again confirm that nothing has changed, just things moved around.

For all that work, though, I'm not completely sure I like this change. Ad hoc and inconsistent though it was for the most part, resource_provider.py used to be "organized" so that things were near other things that they related to and/or invoked. Now they're in effectively arbitrary order.

Sooo... I don't know how best to vote here. I guess I'll +1 to ack that the change is correct as far as it's advertised ("does what it says on the tin"), but wait for other reviewers to chime in on whether it's a good idea philosophically.

In the meantime, perhaps we should reverse the order of this patch and its successor so as not to hold up overall de-list-ification.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-03-08 23:58:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

We talked about this in irc and agreed to kill this in favor of a more robust refactoring of the entire file. I'll pull this out of the stack."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-03-09 00:42:21.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

we decided to not do this now, as it is just too weird'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-08 20:11:31.000000000', 'message': 'Reorder objects.resource_provider

Reorder the classes and methods in resource_provider.py:

* classes
* public module methods
* private module methods

Within each group, ordering is alpha.

Change-Id: Iae3b0002de6919b0497669602115a4fde2544816
'}]
commit_message:
Reorder objects.resource_provider

Reorder the classes and methods in resource_provider.py:

* classes
* public module methods
* private module methods

Within each group, ordering is alpha.

Change-Id: Iae3b0002de6919b0497669602115a4fde2544816

Working now

http://logs.openstack.org/81/640481/2/check/grenade-heat/213c87d/logs/grenade.sh.txt.gz#_2019-03-01_22_24_33_747'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2019-03-05 20:44:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

+1 only because we need to discuss about the name of the variable? :)'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-03-07 11:32:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

So... we don't want to run tests after the upgrade either? May be have different flags for BASE/TARGET?

As it does not change the current behavior unless the flag is changed, I'm fine with it."}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2019-03-07 11:51:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> So... we don't want to run tests after the upgrade either? May be
 > have different flags for BASE/TARGET?
 > 
 > As it does not change the current behavior unless the flag is
 > changed, I'm fine with it.

The flag is intended for projects which depends on Heat but who need to run only the tests specific for their project.

It is always possible to run the (fully) tempest tests afterwards, as you can see in this work-in-progress native Zuul v3 Grenade job for Heat (in the wrong repository  because I was really testing the base native native Grenade job):
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/639774/
The test above runs all the integration tests, and also few of the tempest tests at the end."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-03-08 16:46:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

I still prefer an inverted variable but whatevs'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2019-03-08 20:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-01 18:09:51.000000000', 'message': 'Allow users to disable the tests run by Grenade

Setting RUN_HEAT_INTEGRATION_TESTS=False disables the Heat
integration tests which are normally executed by Grenade
after the deployment of the base environment and after the upgrade.
This is useful when Heat is used in a Grenade job of another
component, where the focus of the testing is not Heat itself,
thus shortening the run-time of the overall Grenade job.

The default behavior is unchanged.

Change-Id: I47b258fecd45ebc08c82df179625bcfb57a32894
'}, {'created': '2019-03-01 21:48:31.000000000', 'message': 'Allow users to disable the tests run by Grenade

Setting RUN_HEAT_INTEGRATION_TESTS=False disables the Heat
integration tests which are normally executed by Grenade
after the deployment of the base environment and after the upgrade.
This is useful when Heat is used in a Grenade job of another
component, where the focus of the testing is not Heat itself,
thus shortening the run-time of the overall Grenade job.

The default behavior is unchanged.

Change-Id: I47b258fecd45ebc08c82df179625bcfb57a32894
'}]
commit_message:
Allow users to disable the tests run by Grenade

Setting RUN_HEAT_INTEGRATION_TESTS=False disables the Heat
integration tests which are normally executed by Grenade
after the deployment of the base environment and after the upgrade.
This is useful when Heat is used in a Grenade job of another
component, where the focus of the testing is not Heat itself,
thus shortening the run-time of the overall Grenade job.

The default behavior is unchanged.

Change-Id: I47b258fecd45ebc08c82df179625bcfb57a32894

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-08 03:28:10.000000000', 'message': 'nova: restart instead of reloading services

There is a bug inside oslo.service which causes calls a stop,
reset and start instead of reset only on SIGHUP which causes
a very inconsistent state of services.

Until this is resolved, we should not reload services but restart
them only.  This patch should be reverted once the related bug
is fixed.

Change-Id: I61e340a4ef5f0980e8c36611c0f78cd06946636b
Related-Bug: #1715374
'}, {'created': '2019-03-08 18:28:01.000000000', 'message': 'nova: restart instead of reloading services

There is a bug inside oslo.service which causes calls a stop,
reset and start instead of reset only on SIGHUP which causes
a very inconsistent state of services.

Until this is resolved, we should not reload services but restart
them only.  This patch should be reverted once the related bug
is fixed.

This patch also removes SUSE jobs from check/gate and into the
experimental queue as they do not have full maintainers at the
moment.

In addition, it moves jobs that have been failing for a long time
such as the aio_distro_lxc to experimental as well, as they have
been problematic.

Change-Id: I61e340a4ef5f0980e8c36611c0f78cd06946636b
Related-Bug: #1715374
'}, {'created': '2019-03-08 18:30:19.000000000', 'message': 'nova: restart instead of reloading services

There is a bug inside oslo.service which causes calls a stop,
reset and start instead of reset only on SIGHUP which causes
a very inconsistent state of services.

Until this is resolved, we should not reload services but restart
them only.  This patch should be reverted once the related bug
is fixed.

This patch also removes SUSE jobs from check/gate and into the
experimental queue as they do not have full maintainers at the
moment.

In addition, it moves jobs that have been failing for a long time
such as the aio_distro_lxc to experimental as well, as they have
been problematic.

Change-Id: I61e340a4ef5f0980e8c36611c0f78cd06946636b
Related-Bug: #1715374
'}]
commit_message:
nova: restart instead of reloading services

There is a bug inside oslo.service which causes calls a stop,
reset and start instead of reset only on SIGHUP which causes
a very inconsistent state of services.

Until this is resolved, we should not reload services but restart
them only.  This patch should be reverted once the related bug
is fixed.

This patch also removes SUSE jobs from check/gate and into the
experimental queue as they do not have full maintainers at the
moment.

In addition, it moves jobs that have been failing for a long time
such as the aio_distro_lxc to experimental as well, as they have
been problematic.

Change-Id: I61e340a4ef5f0980e8c36611c0f78cd06946636b
Related-Bug: #1715374

commit_message:
Use authorize instead of enforce for policies

After fully implementing policies in code, the authorize method
can be safely used and its a safeguard against introducing
policies for some API which are not properly defined in the code.

Change-Id: I499f13c34027b217bf1de905f829f36ef919e3b8

commit_message:

automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/stein.

commit_message:
Add the option to define Ntp Server for standalone deployments

Running standalone deployments in alternate Zuul setups
requires different NTP servers. This review offers the
option to define different NTP servers.

Change-Id: I1d876feb06b0406e615999b83d948d88ab9ab680

Sorry, missed that entirely.

If you choose to use it, you can do it and stay within the column limit. Specifically, for your example, that will be:

         network_info['network_allocations']}"}, {'account_id': 7102, 'date': '2019-01-22 05:49:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Friendly ping for folks from NetApp to have a look at this patch, please..."}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-02-04 10:14:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

will be tested downstream and reviewed by NetApp team after "Manage/Unmanage DHSS=True" patch is proposed'}, {'account_id': 7102, 'date': '2019-03-05 08:46:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> will be tested downstream and reviewed by NetApp team after
 > "Manage/Unmanage DHSS=True" patch is proposed

friendly reminder given that the patch is now proposed.'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-03-07 16:21:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

This improvement is harmless as is, so I am just -1'ing to invoke the following discussion here.

This ideally should behave appropriately with the Manage/Unmanage in DHSS=True feature. So, for the NetApp driver, it should also return those ports in the backend details. However, the ports are not provided when managing the share server.

The way I recommend to solve this is to just add a --driver-options ports=<uuid1>,<uuid2>,... to the share-server-manage command when managing NetApp share servers, and the driver would inspect the driver_options parameter in the manage_server driver method, and pretty much just return them in the server_details dict. This is simple and easy to do.

But, if Maurice is ok with not having the ports information on managed share servers, I believe we could merge as-is, because it is harmless anyway, and then implement the suggestion above separately.

Waiting for your response Maurice."}, {'account_id': 18816, 'date': '2019-03-08 15:04:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hi Rodrigo, good observation.
I'm fine with merging as is, because I prefer smaller commits.

We should definitely add your suggestion. It improves the experience, when managed shares/share servers behave the same."}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-03-08 20:26:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
NetApp cDOT store port IDs and addresses at share server backend details

Network allocation is made accessible to administrators. It is now easier to
find the port in neutron, if it has been changed or deleted.
Change-Id: I65911b6bf59a4d57fc39d67e6faa4f84422be806

commit_message:
Remove admin test_l3_agent_scheduler API test module

Tests from this module are duplicated by same tests in
neutron-tempest-plugin repo.
Tests are in [1] module in this repo.

Both removed tests got 0% failure rate according to status.openstack.org
page.

It was discussed with QA PTL and he confirmed that those tests can
be removed from tempest. See [2] for details. Also ML thread about
this test removal notification[3].

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin/tree/neutron_tempest_plugin/api/admin/test_l3_agent_scheduler.py
[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-qa/%23openstack-qa.2019-03-01.log.html#t2019-03-01T16:18:32
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003574.html

Change-Id: I28f3bab54c25463d584db5398920d467a04bccf0

[{'account_id': 30000, 'date': '2019-03-08 15:38:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-03-08 15:38:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 30000, 'date': '2019-03-08 15:45:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 30000, 'date': '2019-03-08 20:53:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 30000, 'date': '2019-03-08 20:55:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 30000, 'date': '2019-03-08 21:14:15.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

subject: Add Douglas Mendizábal candidacy for Barbican PTL
messages:
[{'account_id': 7973, 'date': '2019-03-08 17:45:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7973, 'date': '2019-03-08 19:37:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-03-08 19:44:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The failing test is "Validate email address is OSF member" and indeed I don't find an OSF Individual member in good standing via the openstackid-resources API:

https://openstackid-resources.openstack.org/api/public/v1/members?filter[]=group_slug==foundation-members&filter[]=email==dmendiza@redhat.com

However searching by name does find this likely profile:

https://www.openstack.org/community/members/profile/9708

If I had to guess, chances are you've missed adding this E-mail address to one of the address fields of that profile. See https://docs.openstack.org/contributors/common/accounts.html#setup-your-openstack-foundation-account for details.'}, {'account_id': 7973, 'date': '2019-03-08 19:56:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Jeremy, you're right, I had not added my @redhat.com email to that profile.  Looks like all is good now.  Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 6088, 'date': '2019-03-08 20:06:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

With the profile update, this candidacy now appears valid.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-03-08 20:55:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

I confirm your eligibility for the Barbican PTL seat.'}]

'}]

[{'created': '2019-03-07 18:21:01.000000000', 'message': "Make heat yaql limits configurable

We need to be able to tune the yaql settings for heat on the udnercloud.
This change exposes heat's yaql limit_iterators and memory_quota
settings via HeatYaqlLimitIterators and HeatYaqlMemoryQuota. This change
also increases the default limit from 1000 to 10000 on the undercloud
installations.

Change-Id: I37669bbf642146e46388950c97ac5123c5b1180e
Closes-Bug: #1817794
(cherry picked from commit 1ed3d2002d7ee5a0954b06de4037092c70a2584f)
"}]
commit_message:
Make heat yaql limits configurable

We need to be able to tune the yaql settings for heat on the udnercloud.
This change exposes heat's yaql limit_iterators and memory_quota
settings via HeatYaqlLimitIterators and HeatYaqlMemoryQuota. This change
also increases the default limit from 1000 to 10000 on the undercloud
installations.

Change-Id: I37669bbf642146e46388950c97ac5123c5b1180e
Closes-Bug: #1817794
(cherry picked from commit 1ed3d2002d7ee5a0954b06de4037092c70a2584f)

commit_message:
[TEST] bionic

Overlayfs backing
ZFS pool location corrected
Only restart networking once - validate bridges
Eatmydata on host and in containers (maybe not being used?)
container /tmp and .ansible into tmpfs
lxc3 compatibility

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/592540
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/589146
Change-Id: Id3e97f3b976e6a2d1c5077e62e0c71b24af85902

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-04 21:27:41.000000000', 'message': 'RFC: Update ingress controller image, ingress cookie annotations

This updates the ingress controller image to v0.23.0, which was
required to add support for configuring cookie max age and expires
for ingresses via annotations on the ingress.

This also removes the --enable-dynamic-configuration flag, as the
flag is no longer valid in 0.23.0 due to the functionality being
a default behavior of the nginx ingress controller in recent
releases

Change-Id: I4917797c43ec973ed0bb311fc305b01f10abd4e5

Update ingress controller image, ingress cookie annotations

This updates the ingress controller image to v0.23.0, which was
required to add support for configuring cookie max age and expires
for ingresses via annotations on the ingress.

This also removes the --enable-dynamic-configuration flag, as the
flag is no longer valid in 0.23.0 due to the functionality being
a default behavior of the nginx ingress controller in recent
releases

Change-Id: I4917797c43ec973ed0bb311fc305b01f10abd4e5

subject: modify RowEvent hash key
messages:
[{'account_id': 27079, 'date': '2019-02-13 02:16:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 27079, 'date': '2019-02-13 02:19:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2019-02-28 16:49:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Technically, 'events' could also be a list, though by convention it is a tuple.

I'm not sure if I've ever seen a use where we've had a RowEvent subclass that wasn't essentially a singleton. I.e. No MyRowEvent instances had different conditions/table name/whatever. If that's the case, then setting the key/hash for set inclusion based on instance variables might not even matter. And I'm not sure what we should do in the case where conditions/table were set, but there was a custom match_fn based on an added attribute in a subclass (other than tell users they needed to specify their own key property).

Not exactly sure the best thing to do here, yet."}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2019-02-28 17:08:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

modify RowEvent hash key

conditions can not be as the hash key, some columns type are list or dict which
can't be hash

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-07 13:32:00.000000000', 'message': 'Fix ansible tasks on python3

The ansible task would be reading the stdout from pipe to know when
that finished. The stopping sentinel for that reading was a binary empty
That was failing on python3 making it hang and consume 100% cpu
Changed the inter sentinel to empty space that works for both
python 2 and 3.

The issue is mentioned on a downstream bug
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1686397

Change-Id: If12c573430ddbd13243003fc16d7cdabf394fb7b
'}]
commit_message:
Fix ansible tasks on python3

The ansible task would be reading the stdout from pipe to know when
that finished. The stopping sentinel for that reading was a binary empty
That was failing on python3 making it hang and consume 100% cpu
Changed the inter sentinel to empty space that works for both
python 2 and 3.

The issue is mentioned on a downstream bug
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1686397

Change-Id: If12c573430ddbd13243003fc16d7cdabf394fb7b

commit_message:
Fix interaction between gitpython and eventlet

The mistral executor uses eventlet patching, but gitpython's subprocess
module is not being properly patched. Patching it manually fix the issues

Change-Id: I49d041b48d9939844bcc3a571819887772caf491
Closes-bug: #1818757

commit_message:

Current ordering of projects is random. This updates the template to
make sure they are always in alphabetical order.

Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-07 18:07:31.000000000', 'message': "Remove vtep-related code from venv testing

ovsdbapp doesn't implement the vtep schema, so starting binaries
for it are unnecessary, and could break if run in an environment
where testing is against installed packaging that separates out
the vtep-related code into its own packages that aren't installed.

Change-Id: I223e2f883264df0e62620f776be0b27125aa8ea2
"}]
commit_message:
Remove vtep-related code from venv testing

ovsdbapp doesn't implement the vtep schema, so starting binaries
for it are unnecessary, and could break if run in an environment
where testing is against installed packaging that separates out
the vtep-related code into its own packages that aren't installed.

Change-Id: I223e2f883264df0e62620f776be0b27125aa8ea2

messages: [{'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-03-08 18:21:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28008, 'date': '2019-03-08 18:33:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 17799, 'date': '2019-03-08 18:47:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2019-03-08 19:10:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-08 18:21:38.000000000', 'message': "zuul: move non-voting jobs to experimental

The non-voting jobs for Gentoo are new and they are not stable so
we need to leave them as experimental until we have some proven
gate history and maintainership.

The SUSE jobs have been breaking often, however, it seems that they
are still in use, so we're going to move them to experimental
now so that those who would like to try to maintain it can work
on it.

Change-Id: I1e586c68fb7167480a68a421f3211470e92a7003
"}]
commit_message:
zuul: move non-voting jobs to experimental

The non-voting jobs for Gentoo are new and they are not stable so
we need to leave them as experimental until we have some proven
gate history and maintainership.

The SUSE jobs have been breaking often, however, it seems that they
are still in use, so we're going to move them to experimental
now so that those who would like to try to maintain it can work
on it.

Change-Id: I1e586c68fb7167480a68a421f3211470e92a7003

subject: Explicitly pin openstack-tox to xenial for <=rocky
messages: [{'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-03-08 01:32:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-03-08 05:44:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2019-03-08 19:37:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-08 01:32:47.000000000', 'message': "Explicitly pin openstack-tox to xenial for <=rocky

In preparation for changing our base nodeset to ubuntu-bionic, be
explicit about running stable/ocata through stable/rocky branches on
ubuntu-xenial in a variant of the openstack-tox abstract job and
limit the previous default nodeset variant to branches which aren't
those.

Change-Id: Iac7884dd570aaaa72f088fa0287345feae0976f0
"}]
commit_message:
Explicitly pin openstack-tox to xenial for <=rocky

In preparation for changing our base nodeset to ubuntu-bionic, be
explicit about running stable/ocata through stable/rocky branches on
ubuntu-xenial in a variant of the openstack-tox abstract job and
limit the previous default nodeset variant to branches which aren't
those.

Change-Id: Iac7884dd570aaaa72f088fa0287345feae0976f0

commit_message:
Add option to set python interpreter for ansible

This patch adds the option to configure the python interpreter
that is used when deploying machines using the ansible deploy
interface.

Also set the default interpreter for tinyipa image with
ansible deploy interface to /usr/bin/python3 on devstack
and marks ironic-standalone job as voting again.

Change-Id: I8eb58fb00980c9e8946e3b3ef77611a9f5212668
Story: #2005159
Task: #29877

commit_message:
Modified archives from spec/classes with transpec tool

Translated RSpec's Syntax deprecated from ruby archives in
Puppet-Cinder/spec/classes.
-Upgrade from RSpec 2 to RSpec 3 on corresponding files.
Partial-Bug: #1816857

Change-Id: I75cd0f348465c91500a8d3b8cd82ab53b3224c04

[{'created': '2019-02-26 16:23:35.000000000', 'message': "Implement new options to enable discard on SSDs

This change implements a new option called 'bdev-enable-discard' to control
behaviour of issuing discards to SSDs on ceph bluestore. The new code tries
to autodetect cases where it should be enabled by default but will allow
forcing if desired.

Change-Id: I7b83605c827eb4058bc4b46c92eb114c11108c93
Closes-Bug: #1788433

commit_message:
Implement new option to enable discard on SSDs

This change implements a new option called 'bdev-enable-discard' to control
behaviour of issuing discards to SSDs on ceph bluestore. The new code tries
to autodetect cases where it should be enabled by default but will allow
forcing if desired.

Change-Id: I7b83605c827eb4058bc4b46c92eb114c11108c93
Closes-Bug: #1788433

directly.

commit_message:
Add explicit testing for project users and the project API

This commit wraps up the project API policy refactor by adding
explicit testing for how project users are expected to behave with the
projects API. A subsequent patch set will remove the now obsolete
project policies in policy.v3cloudsample.json.

Change-Id: I2832f3c3df94edc95d4808b2cf342d85758f4044
Related-Bug: 968696
Closes-Bug: 1750660

commit_message:
WIP: Implement scope_type checking for project API

This change incorporate system scope support for reader roles in the
projects API. Subsequent patches will implement:

  - system member
  - system admin
  - domain reader
  - domain member
  - domain admin
  - project reader
  - project member
  - project admin

Change-Id: I23e2ef9dd5d30fd070681622a7bd14471d290523
Partial-Bug: 1750660

commit_message:
Change update_host_allocations() for new affinity

The update_host_allocations() function, called for update instance
reservation, assumes that there are no duplicate host ids in the
given arguments and it removes *all* the allocations for the given
host id.

However, this is not the only case when affinity=True/None policy is
in play. This patch changes the function to be aware of how many
allocations should be removed.

Blueprint: no-affinity-instance-reservation
Change-Id: Ia0398543e0a8224b981ec7a515698d3e6d533248

[{'created': '2018-12-26 02:53:16.000000000', 'message': 'Change pickup_hosts() to support affinity=True

The pickup_hosts() fuction, called for create/update/reallocate
instance reservation, assumes affinity=False to return sets of
host ids to add/remove.

For preparation to support affinity=True, this patch changes
pickup_hosts() to return lists of hosts ids to add/remove
allowing duplicate host ids which represents number of instances
to reserve on that host.

Blueprint: no-affinity-instance-reservation
Change-Id: If1f4d7c3aee91dc32a173bd4ae598d194f38b3ea

commit_message:
Change pickup_hosts() for affinity=True/None

The pickup_hosts() function, called for create/update/reallocate
instance reservation, assumed affinity=False and returned sets of
host ids to add/remove.

To support affinity=True/None, this patch changes pickup_hosts()
to return lists of hosts ids to add/remove allowing duplicate host
ids according to the number of instances to reserve on that host.

Blueprint: no-affinity-instance-reservation
Change-Id: If1f4d7c3aee91dc32a173bd4ae598d194f38b3ea

commit_message:
Use latest Oxygen release instead of snapshot

Oxygen daily snapshots are not built any more on ODL's nexus page [1].
The latest release is available [2], so let's use that to fix all
Oxygen based CI jobs.

[1] https://nexus.opendaylight.org/content/repositories/opendaylight.snapshot/org/opendaylight/integration/karaf/
[2] https://nexus.opendaylight.org/content/repositories/opendaylight.release/org/opendaylight/integration/karaf/

Change-Id: I76592d9bf80dd872051af8b2d127036fccf475ab

Downvote is for the indents not marked [unrelated], and _increment_provider_generation; those are worth fixing here. I'll throw a fup for the other things I noticed.

Where I'm kind of coming from here is, if we're putting together new files, they may as well be as close to 100% "clean" as we can reasonably get them. That's a superset of "no warnings in my IDE", which is where a lot of these came from. (Surely we will encounter some such warnings that are just unreasonable and we'll just accept them; but I don't think that applies to any of these.)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-03-01 16:31:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

[{'created': '2019-02-28 20:36:18.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Move Allocation and AllocationList to own module

This is a precursor to getting rid of the AllocationList
class in favor of operating an native python lists.

This is a WIP because:

* The allocations retry functional test is failing and I haven't
  had a chance to investigate yet.

* Some of the changes made to prepare for the move (such as creating
  a unit/objects/base.py) might be better in patches prior to main
  change.

Once objects/allocation.py exists and is well-formed, the next
step will be to get rid of AllocationList similar to [1] but more
complex as there are write operations to deal with.

[1] I0066fc8fa9b61196ea99e35e780a7d123612023f

commit_message:
Move Allocation and AllocationList to own module

This is a precursor to getting rid of the AllocationList
class in favor of operating on native python lists.

When objects/allocation.py exists and is well-formed, the next
step will be to get rid of AllocationList similar to [1] but more
complex as there are write operations to deal with.

[1] I0066fc8fa9b61196ea99e35e780a7d123612023f

Change-Id: Ic673dfa95f6c8e42692c6287fb8d7cc27ee6cbf6

While it is great to see extension to the implementation I see some problems with it:
- there is no find-able API reference. https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/instance-ha/?expanded=list-notifications-detail,show-notification-details-detail doesn't describe this new field (and more the type of it)
- progress_details seem to be currently on the blueprint/spec level in the Masakari itself. At least https://review.openstack.org/#/c/640798/ (which pretend to be the implementation) has not even landed yet
- please fix the patch dependencies. SDK can not/should not depend on the change to masakariclient, since SDK doesn't use it. revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-04 06:35:31.000000000', 'message': 'Add support to get progress details of notification

In microversion 1.1, Masakari supports to return ``progress_details``
information of the notification in ``GET /notifications/{notification_id}``
API. Added ``progress_details`` attribute to Notification class to read
the progress_details of the notification.

commit_message:
Add support to get recovery workflow details

In microversion 1.1, Masakari supports to return ``recovery_workflow_details``
information of the notification in ``GET /notifications/{notification_id}``
API. Added ``recovery_workflow_details `` attribute to Notification class
to read the recovery_workflow_details of the notification.

Change-Id: I639fd38312c88522ac6dc628eb3b798066cca74d

commit_message:
Convert the driver_options to a dictionary

This patch converts the cinder interface driver_options to a
dictionary so it can be pickled between processes.  This patch
also calls query.get() prior to join() so we don't run into
a deadlock.

Change-Id: I67fa8b9b2733440b8e8a373a8f89a0834144ea7e

commit_message:
PowerMax driver - do an rdf_group check earlier

When creating a replicated volume we first create a source volume
before checking that an rdf_group exists.  If an rdf_group does not
exist a lengthy rollback is initiated.  This fix prevents that.

Change-Id: I432cb8c904536d63c1877ee0768f2b979723bc3c

subject: PowerMax driver - handle special case where IG exists

commit_message:
PowerMax driver - handle special case where IG exists

An 'Initiator' does not show up in the initiatior list unless
it is part of a masking view or has previously been logged on.
However these initiators can still be part of an 'Initiator Group'
and an attempt to create a new 'Initiator Group' will fail as
an 'Initiator' cannot be belong to more than one 'Initiator Group'.
Handling this special case and bringing the initiator group check
before the storage group logic so rollback, if required, is tidier.

Change-Id: I62f8a5d75d82352875b179f3e6e1a3f343bb531d

commit_message:
PowerMax driver -  move pagination code to request

Moving pagination code within the requests so that all responses
can leverage it if they have the necessary keys e.g. count, maxPageSize,
expirationTime, id and resultList.

Change-Id: Ia1c03b157bdf8d763084c5409bca740d4f6c60d4

commit_message:
PowerMax driver - do the portgroup check earlier

If a portgroup does not exist, then this check should be done early in
the creation of a new masking view process, so no rollback action is
required on failure.

Change-Id: I02d8a37aa0551e3105dbffa7d1421c799e9e1753

commit_message:
Makes default docker_prep_prefix distro dependent

Instead of using hardcoded centos value as default, now
docker_prep_prefix defaults to <distro>-binary-

Remove the sed commands in the prep script and instead
use ansible's yaml dict utils.

Change-Id: I13ff69e2d4a58887aeb49cd447589543405d6b1b

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-07 20:32:19.000000000', 'message': 'Revert assertion made about SIGHUP behavior for non-daemon services

Way back in I2a73d3872a302fcfac1a6ee844a44faa9569b3dd, the assertion was
made that processes running in the foreground should have different SIGHUP
behavior than those that are in the background. While dubious, this statement
is definitely untrue for services that are run under a supervisor in
foreground mode (which is pretty much everybody with systemd). That assumption
was causing bugs in several projects where SIGHUP was not calling Service.reset(),
but instead restarting the entire process, which is very impactful and not the
goal of a SIGHUP, which should be a lightweight reload.

Change-Id: I57f5619727d0b146245cf07d69e223f3b64652ca
Closes-Bug: #1794708
Closes-Bug: #1715374
'}]
commit_message:
Revert assertion made about SIGHUP behavior for non-daemon services

Way back in I2a73d3872a302fcfac1a6ee844a44faa9569b3dd, the assertion was
made that processes running in the foreground should have different SIGHUP
behavior than those that are in the background. While dubious, this statement
is definitely untrue for services that are run under a supervisor in
foreground mode (which is pretty much everybody with systemd). That assumption
was causing bugs in several projects where SIGHUP was not calling Service.reset(),
but instead restarting the entire process, which is very impactful and not the
goal of a SIGHUP, which should be a lightweight reload.

Change-Id: I57f5619727d0b146245cf07d69e223f3b64652ca
Closes-Bug: #1794708
Closes-Bug: #1715374

commit_message:
add missing libvirt package for suse

the package pythonX-libvirt-python was missing for the bindep.txt
and it's necessary for nova-compute under opensuse as it provides
the libvirt module

Change-Id: I165cf5a9bc75d3645805bece5f2f8bce38fbb64b

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-19 18:37:30.000000000', 'message': 'Support self-signed certificates docker registry

If you want to run a docker registry for development purposes with self-signed
certificates, and use this registry to push your requirements wheel, the loci
build process would fail at fetching the wheels.

This brings support for self-signed certificates registries by:
- Allowing to skip protocol_detection: If protocol_detection happens on a https
  registry, urllib2 would not throw an HTTPError or URLError, and protocol
  returned by default would be HTTP, which would then cause issues by not
  using SSL to fetch data. There is no point to "detect" things if we
  provide an argument to the users.
- If the protocol is correctly given as HTTPs, no certificate is passed into
  the urllib ssl contexts by default, which would only work with globally
  valid certificates. This patch also adds an option to bypass the verification
  of certificates when the user provides `REGISTRY_SSL_NOVERIFY`.

Change-Id: Ib00bbc9cc63d70a88dbf8b23a518553d6134d332

commit_message:
Support self-signed certificates docker registry

If you want to run a docker registry for development purposes with
self-signed certificates, and use this registry to push your
requirements wheel, the loci build process would fail at fetching the
wheels.

This brings support for self-signed certificates registries by:
- Allowing to skip protocol_detection: If protocol_detection happens on
  a https registry, urllib2 would not throw an HTTPError or URLError,
  and protocol returned by default would be HTTP, which would then cause
  issues by not using SSL to fetch data. There is no point to "detect"
  things if we provide an argument to the users.
- If the protocol is correctly given as HTTPs, no certificate is passed
  into the urllib ssl contexts by default, which would only work with
  globally valid certificates. This patch also adds an option to bypass
  the verification of certificates when the user provides
  `REGISTRY_SSL_NOVERIFY`.

Change-Id: Ib00bbc9cc63d70a88dbf8b23a518553d6134d332

commit_message:
For OpenSUSE Leap, use more recent version of zVMCloudConnector

When building requirements image, contraints try to bring in 0.3.5
version of zVMCloudConnector, however this one requires python
version at most 3.5. However Leap 15 only has python 3.6.

Change-Id: I15f57006246059ead08d2cbc4ee494b3891e2081

commit_message:
Fixup zuul reproducer readme doc - move keys note remove images

As noted in [1] (issue 5) we should no longer need to import
the images. Also moves the keys note to the initial setup as
it is imperative and easy to miss where it is.

[1] https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/task/765

Change-Id: I8a4303a72c9c05cb463c604d19245fdc042689be

commit_message:
Add legacy 3 nodes nodeset based on Ubuntu bionic

We are migrating all the legacy jobs running on Bionic nodesets.

This commit adds the bionic legacy nodeset of 3 nodes for ha jobs,
for example- neutron-tempest-dvr-ha-multinode-full

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2018-December/000837.html

Change-Id: Ieef62d7c733694a50707f9670ff370e6c7b90b44

commit_message:
Revert "Modify roles to remove unused services"

This reverts commit 52fb87ce976d78450f141716cec779cd1daba134.

The patch resulted in pacemaker not being configured properly, and
making the OVB jobs fail.

Closes-Bug: #1818994
Change-Id: I5b852ad87a2c79b04ca860ce181bdccd1641247c

For what it's worth, I don't think this is necessary. This stuff is usually handled by a deployment tool and the operator will get a warning about the deprecation.
